body: It certainly doesn't look good in the SNAPSHOT. Does anyone know the chain of events that led up to the current SNAPSHOT condition? I know there was something about a callback being called many times all at once, but that wasn't an issue in 1.10.0...
https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/pull/6772/commits/76a4e18e5120c8c8e0198707d68101c543b3a2c4 (as part of #6772) seems to be the culprit.
It looks like the changed code should only apply to MacOS, no? It seems to cause issues on Windows...
I have the same issue on macOS too, I'll try to upload another video for it soon

This is the behaviour using macOS.. Even weirder than Windows xD

https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5543339/156842860-87f58c4f-f149-4704-926f-313d244966fc.mp4

This change is definitely not needed for Windows (and probably not for Linux either), so we could toggle this behaviour depending on the platform. Since this hadn't been an issue before #6772, it'd be nice if someone with a Mac could check, whether this change is needed for _every_  1.10.1-SNAPSHOT LWJGL 3 app on macOS or only when the gdx-lwjgl3-glfw-awt-macos extension is used. 

Getting rid of the `postRunnable` call would also allow us to revert https://github.com/libgdx/libgdx/commit/a5286e70f1ee279859ee8e8cc798b8444d458aaf.

With a bit more dig in the issue, I'd say that probably the real fix could be the use of a different thread to handle GLFW input events.. This would also fix the issue that when dragging on Windows the rendering freeze (like explained here https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/2074#issuecomment-1089094608)

issue.title: Incorrect viewport size after window resizing on macOS with HDPIMode.Logical
issue.body:
Seems to be caused by commit a5286e70f1ee279859ee8e8cc798b8444d458aaf , specifically where:
`gl20.glViewport(0, 0, width, height);`
was replaced with
`gl20.glViewport(0, 0, getWidth(), getHeight());`

This results in the viewport size being set to logical pixels and not true pixels, which results in incorrect dimensions if display scaling is not 1. Some gl operations (viewport, scissor, etc) require true pixels in all cases.

I can reproduce this on my M1 mac (display scale of 2), the viewport renders in the bottom-left quadrant of the window. As a temporary workaround I can call `Gdx.gl.glViewport(0, 0, Gdx.graphics.getBackBufferWidth(), Gdx.graphics.getBackBufferHeight());` in my application's resize method.

issue.title: title bar mouse click freezes window

repository.name: glfw
repository.description: A multi-platform library for OpenGL, OpenGL ES, Vulkan, window and input

issue.body:
When moving or resizing the window, drawing the window gets freezed. (due to glfwPollEvents not returning)
It can be solved by calling the draw function from the functions given to glfwSetWindowSizeCallback and glfwSetWindowPosCallback

But when title bar is mouse clicked (without moving) the draw function is also not called. I would expect to have a callback for this event in order to apply the same solution that was done for moving and sizing.

Is there any callback for this?

body:
[In my own repo](https://github.com/naphipps/NP-Engine), I fixed this issue and [glfw's #2074](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/2074). The issue is that Windows starts an infinite loop during their window procedures to handle window resizing and moving -- and it starts that loop on a mousedown event on the titlebar/caption.

(I personally recommend that libgdx and glfw should not fix this unless they expose their loops to the user.)

Basically, my fix was to handle window sizing and moving directly/natively, and avoided calling Window's DefWindowProc so those infinite loops were avoided and my application loop could continue (in which, I handle window sizing/moving/etc). GLFW defers windows sizing and moving to DefWindowProc, so this issue is not their doing either... I think this behavior from DefWindowProc is a necessary evil for things to work "out of the box", but I wish their documentation would explain these things better... Anyways, I recommend you handle window sizing/moving directly/natively in a way that allows your application loop to continue. If you only care about rendering, then rendering in another can help but won't prevent the application loop from getting interrupted.

Specifically, I ended up just subclassing the window procedure. Feel free to take a look at my [repo NP-Engine](https://github.com/naphipps/NP-Engine). Under include/Window/Detail/Glfw, you'll find my implementation in GlfwWindow.hpp

I wrote more in the comments of [glfw's #2074](https://github.com/glfw/glfw/issues/2074), so feel free to head over their for more details in case I missed something here.

issue.title: Fix LWJGL3 window not updating on resize. Resolves #6808
issue.body:
Since #6772, libGDX users have had an issue on the LWJGL3 platform when resizing the libGDX window on Windows. When players drag the window border, it does not call update. This results in black, unrendered areas until the user releases the mouse button. See #6808. This particularly impacts all tool developers who depend on UI reacting to window resize.

This fix, courtesy of @BambooBandit, addresses this problem. As noted in the issue, this only affects Windows users, so the fix should not be applied to Linux or Mac. Thank you.
